newsitem.title: JAPAN: BOJ says recovery continuing, private demand firmer.
newsitem.headline: BOJ says recovery continuing, private demand firmer.

text.p: Japan's economy is continuing its gradual recovery, with private demand becoming firmer, Masayuki Matsushima, director of the Bank of Japan's Research and Statistics Department, said on Wednesday.
He added that the mechanism for a self-sustainable recovery was growing stronger.
"The gradual economic recovery is continuing, while private demand is becoming more solid," Matsushima said.
"The mechanism for a self-sustainable economic recovery is increasing," he added.
He attributed the improvement in big manufacturers' business sentiment to a better environment for production.
For example, exports are increasing, as well as investment in machinery, and the car industry is also doing very well, Matsushima said.
But sentiment worsened for big non-manufacturers, partly due to a peaking out of public works spending and housing investment, he said.
Problem loans and increasing competition from deregulation contributed to the weaker sentiment, he said.
Matsushima said the impact of the consumption tax hike, recent weak stock prices, a fiscal tightening and various structural reforms are clouding the outlook.
However, supply and demand conditions, employment and capital investment plans are steadily improving despite some fluctuations, he said.
Corporate business plans for 1997/98 are also generally firm, Matsushima said.
"Although there are some effects seen from the consumption tax hike, overall it (the economy) is firm," he said.
He added that the consumption tax hike to five percent from three percent on April 1 will likely affect businesses towards June.
The increase in exports from the weakness in the yen against the dollar has generally contributed positively to the economy, Matsushima said.
But an economic cycle centring on domestic private demand is steadily appearing, he said, adding that domestic demand contributed much more to company sales than external demand.
Pressure on businesses from various structural reforms will lessen as their content becomes clearer. Problem loans are also being addressed, Matsushima said.

Asked about the planned increase in capital spending by financial firms in 1997/98, he said the firms are increasing their spending to cope with stronger competition, adding that previously such spending has been dampened by the urgent need to address their bad loan problems.
